{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox event | title = Aliso Canyon gas leak | image =File:Aliso Canyon gas leak site, Dec. 14, 2015 (23389378449).jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = Aliso Canyon relief well being drilled on December 14, 2015 | time = | duration = {{start date|2015|10|23}} – {{end date|2016|02|18}} | date = | venue = | location = [[Aliso Canyon Oil Field]], [[Porter Ranch, Los Angeles|Porter Ranch]], [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] | coordinates = {{coord|34|18|54|N|118|33|51|W|region:US-CA_type:event|display=inline,title}} | also_known_as = Porter Ranch gas leak / blowout | type = [[Gas leak]] [[Blowout (well drilling)]] | theme = | cause = | first_reporter = | budget = | patron = <!-- or |patrons= --> | organisers = <!-- or |organizers= --> | filmed_by = | participants = | outcome = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | reported deaths = | reported injuries = | reported missing = | reported property damage = | burial = | inquiries = | inquest = | coroner = | arrests = | suspects = | accused = | convicted = | charges = | trial = | verdict = | convictions = | sentence = | publication_bans = | litigation = | awards = | url = | blank_label = <!-- or |blank_data= --> | blank1_label = <!-- or |blank1_data= --> | blank2_label = <!-- or |blank2_data= --> | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | notes = }} {{Location map | USA Los Angeles Metropolitan Area | width = 250 |float= right | caption = Gas leak site shown within the [[Los Angeles metropolitan area]] | AlternativeMap = USA Los Angeles Metropolitan Area location map.svg | lat_deg = 34.315093 | lon_deg = -118.564096 | label = Aliso Canyon }}
[[File:Aliso Canyon leak well pad 4 Credit- Earthworks (23863773066).jpg|thumb|Aliso Canyon SS 25 wellhead, December 17, 2015. Note subsidence craters at center, apparently from the attempts to plug the leaking well.]]
The '''Aliso Canyon gas leak''' (also called '''Porter Ranch gas leak'''<ref name=wilcox/> and '''Porter Ranch gas blowout'''<ref>Matt Ferner, Lydia O’Connor (8 January 2016) [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/california-methane-gas-leak_us_568f004de4b0cad15e644090 Here’s What It’s Like To Live Next To California’s Gas Blowout Catastrophe]</ref>) was a massive [[natural gas]] leak that was discovered by SoCalGas employees on October 23, 2015.<ref name="scpr.org">Sharon McNary (10 February 2016) [http://www.scpr.org/news/2016/02/10/57348/sorting-out-porter-ranch-facts-vs-rumors/ Sorting out Porter Ranch facts vs. rumors]</ref> Gas was escaping from a [[Oil well|well]] within the Aliso Canyon's [[Aliso Canyon Oil Field|underground storage facility]] in the [[Santa Susana Mountains]] near [[Porter Ranch, Los Angeles]].<ref name=abrams>{{cite web| url=http://www.dailynews.com/general-news/20151219/two-months-in-porter-ranch-gas-leak-compared-to-bp-gulf-oil-spill| author=Abram S| title=Two months in, Porter Ranch gas leak compared to BP Gulf oil spill| publisher=Los Angeles Daily News |date=December 19, 2015 |accessdate=December 27, 2015}}</ref> This second-largest gas storage facility of its kind in the United States belongs to the [[Southern California Gas Company]], a subsidiary of [[Sempra Energy]]. On January 6, 2016, [[Governor of California|Governor]] [[Jerry Brown]] issued a [[state of emergency]].<ref name=barboza>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-brown-declared-emergency-at-porter-ranch-amid-massive-gas-leak-20160106-story.html| author=Tony Barboza| title=Brown declares state of emergency at Porter Ranch amid massive gas leak |newspaper=[[The Los Angeles Times]] |date=January 6, 2016| accessdate=January 7, 2016}}</ref> The Aliso gas leak's [[carbon footprint]] is said to be larger than the [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill|''Deepwater Horizon'' leak]] in the Gulf of Mexico.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/california-methane-gas-leak-more-damaging-than-deepwater-horizon-disaster-a6794251.html| author=Tim Walker| title=California methane gas leak 'more damaging than Deepwater Horizon disaster'| newspaper=The Independent| date=January 2, 2016 | accessdate=July 6, 2017}}</ref> On February 11, 2016, the gas company reported that it had the leak under control.<ref name=socalgas/> On February 18, 2016, state officials announced that the leak was permanently plugged.
An estimated {{Convert|97,100|tonnes}} (0.000097 [[Gigatonne|Gt]]) of [[methane]] and {{Convert|7,300|tonnes}} of [[ethane]] were released into the atmosphere,<ref name="Conley2016">Conley et al., ''Methane emissions from the 2015 Aliso Canyon blowout in Los Angeles, CA''. In: ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' (2016), {{DOI|10.1126/science.aaf2348}}.</ref> The initial effect of the release increased the estimated 5.3 Gt of methane in the Earth's atmosphere by about 0.002%, diminishing to half that in 6-8 years.
It was widely reported to have been the worst single natural gas leak in U.S. history in terms of its environmental impact.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|title = Porter Ranch gas leak permanently capped, officials say|url = http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-porter-ranch-gas-leak-permanently-capped-20160218-story.html|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|access-date = February 18, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-35659947 |title=California methane leak 'largest in US history' |author=Matt McGrath |publisher=BBC |date=February 26, 2016 |accessdate=February 26, 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2016/02/26/3754378/gas-leak-largest-ever/| title = The Massive Methane Blowout In Aliso Canyon Was The Largest in U.S. History| website = ThinkProgress| access-date = February 26, 2016}}</ref> By comparison, the entire rest of the [[South Coast Air Basin]] combined emits approximately 413,000 tonnes of methane and 23,000 tonnes of ethane annually.<ref name="Wunch2016">{{cite journal|last1=Wunch|first1=Debra|last2=Toon|first2=Geoffrey C.|last3=Hedelius|first3=Jacob K.|last4=Vizenor|first4=Nicholas|last5=Roehl|first5=Coleen M.|last6=Saad|first6=Katherine M.|last7=Blavier|first7=Jean-François L.|last8=Blake|first8=Donald R.|last9=Wennberg|first9=Paul O.|title=Quantifying the loss of processed natural gas within California's South Coast Air Basin using long-term measurements of ethane and methane|journal=Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics|volume=16|issue=22|year=2016|pages=14091–14105|issn=1680-7324|doi=10.5194/acp-16-14091-2016}}</ref>
==Facility== After oil was discovered at Aliso Canyon in 1938, [[J. Paul Getty]]'s Tidewater Associated Oil Company produced oil and gas until the Sesnon-Frew reservoir, the largest reservoir within the [[oil field]], was depleted in the early 1970s. On December 18, 1968, a blowout and fire, destroying equipment but causing no injuries, occurred at one of the wells when an operator attempted to remove two gas-lift valves.<ref name=lat>{{cite news|author1=Zahira Torres, Frank Shyong|title=Leaking gas well in Porter Ranch area lacked a working safety valve|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/california/la-me-0104-gas-leak-20160104-story.html|accessdate=January 20, 2016|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=January 3, 2016}}</ref> Getty sold his portion of the field to [[Pacific Lighting Company]], a gas company, which repurposed it to gas storage in 1972. As opposed to current practice, older wells were not sealed to the surrounding rock formation, including their often more than one mile of steel casing. Today, "cement from the surface of the ground to the bottom of the well [...] makes the casings stronger and protects them from water."<ref name=maddaus/> The Aliso Canyon natural gas storage facility contains 115 wells tapping a reservoir that "hold[s] up to 86 billion cubic feet of natural gas for distribution to residences, businesses, and electric utilities in the L.A. basin".<ref name=ud>{{cite news|author1=Herman K. Trabish|title=Historic Los Angeles methane leak puts natural gas emissions under scrutiny|url=http://www.utilitydive.com/news/historic-los-angeles-methane-leak-puts-natural-gas-emissions-under-scrutiny/411060/|accessdate=January 20, 2016|work=Utility Dive|publisher=Industry Dive|date=December 21, 2015}}</ref> The field is the second largest storage facility of its kind in the United States.<ref name=abrams/>
==Discovery of leak== Southern California Gas Company said the leak in well SS-25 was discovered "on October 23 during one of its twice-daily well observations."<ref name=ud/><ref>South Coast Air Quality Management District (23 January 2016)[http://www.aqmd.gov/home/library/public-information/2016-news-archives/aliso-canyon-hb-order-issued-pr SCAQMD Hearing Board Orders SoCalGas to Enact Comprehensive Program to Cut Odors and Air Pollution from Aliso Canyon Gas Leak ]</ref> Residents of the nearby Porter Ranch reported what they thought was a home with a major leak on October 23, 2015. SoCal Gas "went from home to home to home, giving everybody the A-OK and [...] didn't admit to having a gas leak until [...] probably around the 28th of October."<ref>Amy Goodman [http://www.democracynow.org/2015/12/30/erin_brockovich_california_methane_gas_leak Erin Brockovich: California Methane Gas Leak is Worst U.S. Environmental Disaster Since BP Oil Spill] Democracy Now, December 30, 2015, retrieved January 11, 2016.</ref>
Local residents believed the gas blowout started before SoCalGas admitted to discovering it, and many residents reported having unexplained illnesses a week or so earlier. According to [[KPCC|KPCC's]] website, some residents posted complaints of earlier symptoms on a Porter Ranch gas leak Facebook page.<ref name="scpr.org"/>
This event has been called a blowout in several news reports. For instance, an February 2016 article in The Orange County Register called "Gas facility that had blowout over Porter Ranch will have to play by new rules." stated "in the case of the blown-out well, the casing is believed to have failed under high pressure, allowing the gas to escape."<ref name="ocregister.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/facility-705395-gas-new.html |title=Gas facility that had blowout over Porter Ranch will have to play by new rules |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=February 24, 2016 |website= |publisher=[[Orange County Register]] |access-date=August 1, 2016 |quote=}}</ref> According to OSHA's website a blowout is "an uncontrolled flow of gas, oil, or other well fluids" from a well."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.osha.gov/SLTC/etools/oilandgas/glossary_of_terms/glossary_of_terms_b.html |title=Oil and Gas Well Drilling and Servicing eTool | Glossary of Terms - B |website=Osha.gov |date= |accessdate=2016-09-16}}</ref>
An article in The Huffington Post entitled "Here’s How Enormous The Methane Blowout Is In California" stated that as of February 1, 2016 the SS-25 well released an estimated 91,000 metric tons of methane gas."The article said that "while this gas blowout has prompted comparisons to BP’s oil well failure in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010 and the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska in 1989, experts say this leak will have further-reaching environmental consequences."<ref name="huffingtonpost.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/california-gas-leak-infographic_us_56aff98ce4b09214b14f54b9 |title=Here's How Enormous The Methane Blowout Is In California |publisher=[[Huffington Post]] |date=2016-02-02 |accessdate=2016-09-16}}</ref>
==Causes== The source of the leak was a metal pipe in a breached {{convert|7|in|adj=on}} [[casing (borehole)|casing]] of injection well "Standard Sesnon 25" (SS 25) that lies {{convert|8,750|ft}} deep.<ref name=abrams/> SoCal Gas had hypothesized that the leak was no more than {{convert|500|ft}} down in the column used to move gas in and out of the well.<ref name=ud/> Well SS 25 was drilled in 1953 and initially had safety valves, which were removed in 1979 because the valves were old and leaking.<ref name=maddaus/> Because the well was not considered "critical, that is, one within 100 feet of a road or a park, or within 300 feet of a home", the valves were merely removed and not replaced. Multiple safety valves had been removed from the Aliso Canyon/Porter Ranch 1950s-era pipes in 1979, and were never replaced, a fact that was also confirmed by a special investigation into the leak by [[Brad_Sherman|Congressman Brad Sherman]]'s office.<ref name=maddaus/><ref name=rt>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UBYpL3JDCzA A Staggering Methane Leak Has Caused a State of Emergency in CA] The Big Picture RT January 7, 2016, retrieved January 11, 2016</ref><ref>[http://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2016/01/19/rep-brad-sherman-doubtful-porter-ranch-facility-leaking-gas-can-be-reopened/ Article in [[CBS]] 19 January 2016] accessed 31 January 2017</ref> The atmospheric scientist Steve Conley said the wellhead in Aliso Canyon was 61 years old and he was not "shock[ed] that it failed".<ref name=sacbee>Edward Oritiz [http://www.sacbee.com/news/local/environment/article53629265.html#storylink=cpy UC Davis scientist key to measuring massive methane leak at Aliso Canyon] Sacramento Bee, January 7, 2016</ref> One reason for the casing failure may have been gas flow not just through the tubing, but also through the casing "in order to meet the demand of a customer", as told by an injection well expert of Texas A&M University interviewed by NPR.<ref>[https://www.npr.org/2016/01/21/463865377/california-examines-safety-of-gas-wells-amid-methane-leak California Examines Safety Of Gas Wells Amid Methane Leak.] NPR All Things Considered, January 21, 2016, retrieved January 22, 2016</ref>
On December 7, 2015, an anonymous video was published that showed a cloud of methane gas hovering over the community of Porter Ranch. The image was captured with an infrared camera, showing the extent of the plume.<ref>{{Citation|title = [NEW - Dec. 11] Aliso Canyon SoCalGas Leak Video|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r1Fyevj25-o|date = December 11, 2015|accessdate = January 19, 2016}}</ref>
==Emissions== Natural gas consists largely of methane, an invisible and odorless [[greenhouse gas]] with a [[global warming potential]] 86 times greater than [[carbon dioxide]] in a 20-year time frame, tailing off to about 29 times the effect of carbon dioxide in a 100-year time frame on a mass per mass basis.<ref>Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Summary for policymakers. in: Climate change 2013: The physical science basis. Contribution of Working Group I to the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Technical report, Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, Cambridge, United Kingdom and New York, NY, USA., 2013</ref> The leak initially released about 44,000 kilograms(kg) of methane per hour or 1,200 tons of methane every day, which in terms of greenhouse gas output per month compares with the equivalent effluvia from 200,000 cars in a year.<ref name=abrams/> On January 14, 2016, ''Time m''agazine compared the 1.6 million lbs of methane released each day to the emissions of 6 coal fired powerplants, 2.2 million cows per day, or 4.5 million cars.<ref>Justin Worland, Heather Jones. [http://time.com/4180692/california-methane-gas-leak-environment/?xid=homepage This Is How Much the California Gas Leak Is Hurting the Planet] Time magazine, January 14, 2016, retrieved January 17, 2016.</ref> As of January 2016, the latest methane measurement per the [[California Air Resources Board]] (Carb) was from December 22, 2015 and had decreased from a peak of 58,000±12,000  kg/h<ref name=ud/> to 30,300 kg/h,<ref name=sacbee/> the equivalent of "more than 1,411,851 cars" by a different calculation using EPA estimates.<ref name=bbc>Paul Blake [https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-35258036 How many cars and burping cows equal the California gas leak?], BBC News, Washington, January 11, 2016</ref> The Aliso gas leak [[carbon footprint]] is referred to as "larger than the [[Deepwater Horizon]] leak in the Gulf of Mexico".<ref name=lip>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lTvQvMAJ6hE California’s Methane Gas Leak Environmental Catastrophe Explained] Antidote, interview with Timothy O’Connor, TheLipTV2, 36 min, January 6, 2016, retrieved January 11, 2016</ref> This single event had a 100-year global warming potential of about 1.5% of the entire annual [[South Coast Air Basin|SoCAB]] methane and carbon dioxide emissions.<ref name=Wunch2016/>
Steve Conley, an atmospheric scientist at [[UC Davis]] and owner of Scientific Aviation, independently measured the gas emissions.<ref name=sacbee/><ref name="Wired-Conley">{{cite web|last1=Zhang|first1=Sarah|title=The Lone Pilot Flying Over California’s Giant Methane Leak|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/01/meet-scientist-flying-methane-leak/|website=Wired|accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref> He sampled the air by flying over the site in his single-engine airplane equipped with an analyzer, which is one of only 3 or 4 of such planes in the country. He said the Aliso Canyon flights were "the hardest [...] I've ever done" because of the headache-inducing smell and sickening turbulence. He doubted the readings initially, and "thought [the instruments] had stopped working because I'd never seen measurement that large before." He had coincidentally been contracted by the [[California Energy Commission]] prior to the gas leak, and said that if he hadn’t been contracted and ready to go, "no one would have known how big [the leak] was."<ref name=sacbee/>
Methane emissions from the Aliso Canyon gas leak were detected by the [[Total Carbon Column Observing Network|TCCON]] site at [[Caltech]] within a day of the start of the leak, but researchers at Caltech did not have an explanation for what was causing something "really weird" over Pasadena until later.<ref name="Fesenmaier">{{cite news|last1=Fesenmaier|first1=Kimm|title=Aliso Canyon, Methane, and Global Climate: A Conversation with Paul Wennberg|url=http://www.scienceandtechnologyresearchnews.com/aliso-canyon-methane-global-climate-conversation-paul-wennberg/|accessdate=12 May 2016|work=Science and Technology Research News|date=April 18, 2016}}</ref> TCCON's monitoring data were used in analyses of the leak to estimate ethane emissions of 7,700 ± 1,700 tonnes using Steve Conley's methane estimate of 97,100 tonnes.<ref name=Wunch2016/><ref name=Conley2016/>
Besides methane, the gas leak contained [[tert-Butylthiol|tert-butyl mercaptan]], [[tetrahydrothiophene]],<ref>[http://oehha.ca.gov/public_info/emergency/alisocanyon.html Aliso Canyon Underground Storage Field in Los Angeles County] Office of Environmental Health Hazard Assessment (OEHHA), January 15, 2016, retrieved January 17, 2016</ref> and [[Methanethiol|methyl mercaptan]], which gives the gas a rotten-egg smell. These odorants have been used for decades and were considered harmless although they can cause nausea and vomiting.<ref name=latimes/> In addition, the gas contains some [[volatile organic compound]]s such as the [[carcinogen]] [[benzene]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name= gazzar/><ref>[http://oehha.ca.gov/public_info/emergency/pdf/SoCalGaspeakbenzenetoDec172015.pdf Peak Benzene Air Levels in the Porter Ranch Community] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160108235032/http://oehha.ca.gov/public_info/emergency/pdf/SoCalGaspeakbenzenetoDec172015.pdf |date=January 8, 2016 }} oehha.ca.gov, January 5, 2016, retrieved January 11, 2016.</ref> The pollutants may have long-term consequences far beyond the region.<ref name=warrick>{{cite web |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2015/12/23/new-infrared-video-reveals-growing-environmental-disaster-in-la-gas-leak/ |author=Warrick W |title=New infrared video reveals growing environmental disaster in L.A. gas leak |publisher=The Washington Post |date=December 24, 2015| access-date=December 27, 2015}}</ref>
===Effect on local community=== Local residents have reported headaches, nausea, and severe nosebleeds.<ref name=abrams/> About 50 children per day saw school nurses for severe nosebleeds.<ref name=lip/> There have been more than usual eye, ear and throat infections.<ref name="rt"/> By December 25, 2015, more than 2,200 families from the Porter Ranch neighborhood had been temporarily relocated, and more than 2,500 households were still being processed.<ref name=gazzar>{{cite web| url=http://www.dailynews.com/environment-and-nature/20151225/porter-ranch-gas-leak-dampens-christmas-spirit-for-those-struggling-to-relocate| author=Gazzar B |title=Porter Ranch gas leak dampens Christmas spirit for those struggling to relocate |publisher=Los Angeles Daily News| date=December 25, 2015 |access-date=December 27, 2015}}</ref> As of January 7, 2016, 2,824 households or about 11,296 people had been temporarily relocated by SoCal Gas,<ref name=bbc/> while more than 6,500 families have filed for help.<ref name=CBS/> Two schools were relocated in January.<ref name=maddaus/>
The community of [[Eight Mile, Alabama]] had a spill of the natural gas [[odorant]] within their community in 2008. Residents continue to experience these symptoms under their long term exposure to mercaptan. The residents say they got very little of the assistance provided to Porter Ranch residents. [[Methanethiol|Methyl mercaptan]] is toxic if inhaled according to its MSDS sheet.<ref name=MSDSmercaptan>{{cite web|url=http://www.cpchem.com/msds/100000013972_SDS_US_EN.PDF | title=Methyl mercaptan MSDS | access-date=March 20, 2017}}</ref> However, it is considered fairly harmless by government and industry officials. Whether it is the source of the illnesses in Porter Ranch and Eight Mile has been a subject of debate.<ref name=latimes>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/projects/la-fi-eight-mile-leak/ |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |title=We cannot breathe:' A poor Alabama town has lived with the rotten egg stench of gas for 8 years" |first=Ivan |last=Penn |date=October 15, 2016 |access-date=15 October 2016}}</ref>
==Closure of well== By the end of November 2015 SoCal Gas had attempted six [[well kill]] procedures to stop the gas flow by pumping a mixture of mud and brine down the well, the last being on November 25.<ref name=maddaus>{{cite news| url=http://www.laweekly.com/news/what-went-wrong-at-porter-ranch-6405804| author=Maddaus G |title=What went wrong at Porter Ranch? |publisher=LA Weekly |date=December 22, 2015| access-date=December 28, 2015}}</ref> The attempts failed because of ice formation and a high upward pressure averaging 2,700 pounds per square inch.<ref name=CBS>Associated Press [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/huge-california-gas-leak-could-take-months-to-fix/ Huge California gas leak could take months to fix] CBS News, January 2, 2016, retrieved January 11, 2016</ref>
On December 4, 2015 SoCal Gas started drilling a [[relief well]] to the caprock, 8,000 feet down, with the help of [[Boots & Coots]], a subsidiary of Halliburton. The relief well is "similar to the relief well BP’s engineers drilled to stop oil flowing into the Gulf of Mexico in 2010 after the [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill|Deepwater Horizon]] disaster".<ref name=ud/> The plan was to pump liquid and cement into the main well once the relief well could vent the gas safely.<ref name=maddaus/><ref name=sahagun/> SoCal Gas estimated the first relief well would be completed by February 24, 2016.<ref name=sahagun>{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/local/california/la-me-porter-ranch-20151228-story.html |author=Sahagan L |title=SoCal Gas pinpoints the site of a leaking well near Porter Ranch| newspaper=The Los Angeles Times |date=December 27, 2015| accessdate=December 28, 2015}}</ref> SoCal Gas planned to drill a secondary relief well, estimating the leak repair to take up until the end of March 2016.<ref name=sahagun/>
After the seventh effort to plug the leak with slurry starting December 22 had created a 25-feet-deep crater around the wellhead, the danger of a [[Blowout (well drilling)|blow out]] increased. The well needed to be stabilized with tension cables and further attempts to plug the well from above were halted. State regulators became more concerned about the wellhead's stability.<ref name=stjohn>{{cite news| url=http://www.latimes.com/local/california/la-me-aliso-well-hole-20160115-story.html |author=St. John P| title=Efforts to plug Porter Ranch-area gas leak worsened blowout risk, regulators say| newspaper=The Los Angeles Times |date=January 15, 2016 |accessdate=January 17, 2016}}</ref>
In January SoCal Gas sought permission to capture the natural gas and possibly incinerate it, but state regulators voted against it, worried about safety.<ref>Sharon McNary [http://ww2.kqed.org/news/2016/01/20/porter-ranch-gas-leak-to-be-stopped-ahead-of-schedule-utility-says Porter Ranch Gas Leak to Be Stopped Ahead of Schedule, Utility Says] KQED, January 20, 2016, accessdate January 22, 2016</ref>
On February 11, 2016, the relief well intercepted the base of the leaking well and the company began pumping heavy fluids to control the flow of gas out of the leaking well.<ref name=socalgas>{{cite web| url=https://www.alisoupdates.com/1443738468372/SoCalGas-Temporarily-Controls-Flow-of-Gas-021116-2.pdf|author=SoCal Gas Press Release|title=SoCal Gas Temporarily Controls Flow of Gas at Leaking Aliso Canyon Well; Initiates Process of Permanently Stopping the Leak|date=February 11, 2016| accessdate=February 11, 2016}}</ref> On February 18, 2016, state officials announced that the leak was permanently plugged.<ref name=":0" />
==Criticism== Steve Conley, the atmospheric scientist that has been measuring the leak's gas emissions, has stated that there was no rapid response plan for this kind of event: "We do not have anything in place to measure giant leaks like this, or to watch them to solve issues." He suggested that contracts needed to be ready so that, "as soon as a leak is spotted you are given a go order and two hours later you're measuring a leak."<ref name=sacbee/>
On January 11, 2016 [[Mitchell Englander]], the Los Angeles City Councilman representing Porter Ranch, criticized SoCal Gas "operating a facility of this magnitude, [...] feeding 20 million addresses" for not having a backup plan, the delay in bringing necessary equipment on site "from the Gulf states like they did in this particular situation" and the delay in catching the brine, oil and chemical mist "landing on people's homes and turning their cars black".<ref name=npr11116>{{cite news|author1=Steve Inskeep, Renee Montagne|title=LA Councilman Compares Porter Ranch Gas Leak To BP Oil Spill But On Land|work=Around the Nation|publisher=NPR|date=January 11, 2016}}</ref>
The [[Center for Biological Diversity]] has criticized Governor Brown's slow response "because state regulators' hands-off approach to underground injection helped set the stage for this catastrophe." The Center also said, "The state has known for years that aging natural gas infrastructure was a disaster waiting to happen, but officials mostly ignored those risks."<ref>David Siders [http://www.sacbee.com/news/politics-government/capitol-alert/article53353615.html#storylink=cpy Jerry Brown declares emergency around Southern California gas leak] The Sacramento Bee, January 6, 2016, retrieved January 11, 2016.</ref>
Experts in [[petroleum engineering]] criticized the delay for not drilling a relief well until six weeks after the leak was known, and for drilling only one relief well instead of two.<ref name=maddaus/>
In January 2016 the [[Associated Press]] reported that SoCal Gas had been under-reporting the levels of benzene in the air surrounding the well.<ref>{{cite news |last=Domonoske|first=Camila|date=January 15, 2016|title=Gas Company Understated Benzene Exposure From California Leak|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/01/15/463178568/gas-company-understated-benzene-exposure-from-california-leak|newspaper=[[NPR]]|access-date=January 18, 2016}}</ref>
==Regulatory reactions== Within two days of discovery, "a dozen or more local and state agencies were involved".<ref name =ud/> The [[California Air Resources Board]] measured methane on the ground near the well, from towers, satellites and airplanes, communicating results to the [[California Energy Commission]] and SoCal Gas.<ref name=arb>{{cite web|author1=Mary Nichols|title=Letter to the CEO of SoCalGas|url=http://www.arb.ca.gov/research/reports/arbletter_to_scg_realisocanyon.pdf|publisher=Air Resources Board|accessdate=January 20, 2016|page=5|format=PDF|date=December 10, 2015}}</ref>{{rp|1}} The Board asked SoCal Gas 18 very detailed questions about the natural gas, basic leakage rate and leak dynamics.<ref name=arb/>{{rp|4–5}} The [[Federal Aviation Administration]] established a [[temporary flight restriction]] over the leak site until March 2016. On December 7, 2016 Los Angeles City Attorney Mike Feuer sued SoCal Gas over its handling of the massive well failure. <ref>http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-gas-leak-porter-ranch-lawsuit-20151207-story.html</ref> On December 15, 2015, the [[County of Los Angeles]] declared a state of emergency.<ref name=wilcox>{{cite news| author = Gregory J. Wilcox |title = LA County declares state of emergency over Porter Ranch gas leak | url = http://www.dailynews.com/environment-and-nature/20151215/la-county-declares-state-of-emergency-over-porter-ranch-gas-leak | work = [[Los Angeles Daily News]] | date = December 15, 2015 | accessdate = December 27, 2015}}</ref>
Feuer's Office went to Court again on December 23, 2015 and secured a judicially enforceable agreement with SoCal Gas for the company to speed up relocation efforts of residents affected by the massive leak. <ref>http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-porter-ranch-judge-20151223-story.html </ref>
Local residents called upon Governor [[Jerry Brown]] to intercede. [[Kathleen Brown]], his sister, is on the board of [[Sempra Energy]],<ref>{{cite web|title = Sempra Energy|url = http://sempra.com/about/governance/board-of-directors.shtml|website = sempra.com|access-date = January 22, 2016}}</ref> which owns [[Southern California Gas]]. The Governor visited the site and the neighborhood on January 4, 2016,<ref>[http://www.caloes.ca.gov/ICESite/Pages/Aliso-Canyon.aspx Alison Canyon Natural Gas Leak] - The California Governor’s Office of Emergency Services (CalOES), State of California</ref> and declared a state of emergency on January 6, 2016. He issued stepped-up inspections and safety measures for all natural gas storage facilities in California; further injections at Aliso Canyon had already been prohibited.<ref name=barboza/>
Local health officials indicated that long-term exposure to certain trace chemicals could lead to health problems.<ref name=abrams/>
In January 2016 two California senators asked the heads of the [[US Department of Justice]] and [[US Department of Transportation]] and the [[Environmental Protection Agency]] for a "legal analysis of any federal authorities that could apply to this incident and storage fields in general" and a "technical analysis of whether Southern California Gas Company could more quickly reduce the gas stored in the facility."<ref>{{cite news|author1=Devin Henry|title=Dems seek feds' help in California methane leak|url=http://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/265748-calif-dems-ask-feds-to-get-involved-in-methane-leak|accessdate=January 20, 2016|work=The Hill|publisher=Capitol Hill Publishing Corp.,|date=January 13, 2016}}</ref> On January 11, four California State senators introduced bills to enact an immediate moratorium on any new injections of natural gas and the use of vintage wells (SB 875), to ensure that SoCal Gas will pay housing, relocation and emergency response costs and prohibit the [[California Public Utilities Commission]] (CPUC) from allocating those costs to ratepayers, and that it will pay the costs to mitigate the greenhouse gas emissions from its utility profits (SB 876).<ref>{{cite news|title=Who Pays to Fix the Aliso Canyon Methane Leak?|date= January 26, 2016|first=Vidhya |last=Prabhakaran |publisher= Davis Wright Tremaine LLP| work=Energy & Environmental Law Blog|url=http://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/who-pays-to-fix-the-aliso-canyon-81190/|access-date = January 27, 2016}}</ref> SB 887 would require all 14 underground natural gas storage facilities to be inspected within the next 12 months and at least annually thereafter; it would also require enhanced safety standards such as the installation of subsurface safety valves, using new leak-detection technology and development of rigorous response plans.<ref>Fran Pavley. [http://sd27.senate.ca.gov/news/2016-01-11-senate-legislation-would-bar-new-gas-injections-aliso-canyon-add-more-stringent-gas Senate legislation would bar new gas injections at Aliso Canyon, add more stringent gas well regulations statewide.] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20160216111216/http://sd27.senate.ca.gov/news/2016-01-11-senate-legislation-would-bar-new-gas-injections-aliso-canyon-add-more-stringent-gas |date=February 16, 2016 }} California State Senate Majority Caucus, January 11, 2016,access date January 20, 2016</ref>
The unavailability of the Aliso Canyon gas storage facility has caused insufficient delivery of gas to [[power plants]], leading to a strained [[electricity grid]]. The CPUC has ordered<!--possibly related http://docs.cpuc.ca.gov/PublishedDocs/Published/G000/M166/K230/166230781.PDF , from http://www.cpuc.ca.gov/aliso/ --> [[Southern California Edison]] to install a 20 [[Megawatt|MW]] (80 [[MWh]]) [[lithium ion battery]] storage capacity at the utility's [[Mira Loma, California|Mira Loma]] [[Electrical substation|substation]] near San Bernardino, California to mitigate power failures during winter.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.utilitydive.com/news/sce-taps-tesla-for-80-mwh-storage-project-to-deal-with-aliso-canyon-gas-sho/426471/ |title=SCE taps Tesla for 80 MWh storage project to deal with Aliso Canyon gas shortage|date= September 16, 2016|work=Utility Dive|accessdate= October 28, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://arstechnica.com/business/2016/09/socal-utility-will-buy-80mwh-of-battery-storage-from-tesla-after-methane-leak/ |title=SoCal utility will buy 80MWh of battery storage from Tesla after methane leak|first=Megan |last=Geuss|work=[[Ars Technica]]|date= September 16, 2016|accessdate= October 28, 2016}}</ref>
==Political reaction== On March 31, 2016 The [[New York Times]] published a magazine feature article about the leak called "The Invisible Catastrophe," noting that in an election year a "menacing disaster that causes mass vomiting and mass nosebleeds in a wealthy, vote-rich community ...is a candidate’s dream." While crediting Governor Jerry Brown as the "only politician who has failed to use the gas leak for political gain," it noted freshman Congressman Steve Knight's acceptance of campaign contributions from SoCalGas' parent company Sempra Energy, and his continued defense of the company into December when he said they were "working on this as diligently as they can." While Knight later called for congressional hearings on the matter, one of his opponents, Democrat [[Bryan Caforio]], quickly seized on the environmental disaster as a central issue of the 25th Congressional race, which according to the Times article "promises to be one of few closely contested races in the House." <ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/03/magazine/the-invisible-catastrophe.html The Invisible Catastrophe] [[The New York Times Magazine]], March 31, 2016</ref>
''The Los Angeles Times'' wrote that no politician is "pursuing the issue as hard as Caforio," who on January 6, 2016, spoke to a group of disgruntled Porter Ranch residents who attended a meeting co-hosted by environmental activist [[Erin Brockovich]]. Caforio "aggressively attacked" his opponent, [[Steve Knight (politician)|Steve Knight]], for his delayed response to the leak.<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/local/california/la-me-0118-porter-ranch-pols-20160118-story.html Porter Ranch gas leak lingers] Los Angeles Times, Jan. 18, 2016</ref><ref>[http://www.nationaljournal.com/s/352854/caforino-chastises-knight-over-porter-ranch-gas-leak Caforio Chastises Knight Over Porter Ranch Gas Leak: Caforio spoke to the area before Knight] National Journal, Jan. 19, 2016</ref> While Knight states he does not want to politicize the disaster, fellow Republican Michael Antonovich, a Los Angeles County supervisor who has voted consistently against regulation efforts, has been outspoken about his determination to hold SoCalGas responsible.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/03/magazine/the-invisible-catastrophe.html The Invisible Catastrophe] The New York Times Magazine, March 31, 2016</ref>
==Aftermath==
Elected officials, including [[Brad_Sherman|Congressman Brad Sherman]] and [[Henry_Stern_(politician)|Senator Henry Stern]], took the position that no decision about whether to reactivate the facility until the health study and an ongoing search for the leak’s cause are complete.<ref>[http://www.dailynews.com/opinion/20170124/in-socalgas-leak-dispute-a-chance-to-meet-in-the-middle Article in [[Los Angeles Daily News]] 24 January 2017] accessed 31 January 2017</ref> [[SoCalGas]] had been repeatedly asking California regulators for permission to resume pumping pressurized natural gas into the ground in Porter Ranch, northeast of Los Angeles, at the depleted oil field, which has continued to be used for storage. Records show the utility has been negotiating this step with regulators for several weeks. Since the multiple investigations into the cause of the leak have not been completed, [[Brad_Sherman|Congressman Brad Sherman]] insisted that the process of reopening the storage facility must proceed with extreme caution. Aliso Canyon is not deemed ready to resume normal operations by regulators or chief politicians that are involved with the oversight of the securing and cleanup of the leak. [[Brad_Sherman|Congressman Brad Sherman]] urged that the gas company be restricted to minimal operations required to prevent power interruptions. The storage field is a primary supplier to gas-powered electric plants. The gas leak has been cited by experts and independent researchers as the largest in U.S. History.<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-porter-ranch-20161101-story.html Article in [[Los Angeles Times]] 1 November 2016] accessed 31 January 2017</ref><ref>[http://www.ecowatch.com/porter-ranch-monster-gas-leak-largest-in-u-s-history-1882181666.html Article in EcoWatch.com 27 February 2016] accessed 31 January 2017</ref>
==Legal consequences== On November 23, 2015, some residents who had been displaced by the leaking gases filed a lawsuit in Los Angeles Superior Court to require that SoCal Gas to disclose information related to the health risks of the gases released. The plaintiffs also had continued to seek damages.<ref>{{Cite news | url = http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-porter-ranch-lawsuit-20151202-story.html | title = Class-action lawsuit filed over Porter Ranch gas leak | newspaper = The Los Angeles Times | access-date = February 26, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.porterranchlawsuit.com/ | title = Porter Ranch SoCalGas Well Blowout Lawsuits | website = Porter Ranch SoCal Gas Leak Lawsuits Center | access-date = February 26, 2016 }}</ref>
In January, it was thought that residents might have filed as many as 1,000 lawsuits.<ref name="huff1">{{cite web | url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/facility-705395-gas-new.html | title=Here’s What It’s Like To Live Next To California’s Gas Blowout Catastrophe | work=The Huffington Post | date=8 January 2016 | accessdate=14 June 2016 | author=Matt Ferner, Lydia O’Connor}}</ref> On February 2, 2016, [[Los Angeles County]] filed criminal charges against [[SoCalGas]] for its failure to report the leak immediately.<ref>{{cite web|last1=St John|first1=Paige|last2=Walton|first2=Alice|title=L.A. County files criminal charges over Porter Ranch gas leak|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-attorney-general-lawsuit-aliso-canyon-leak-20160202-story.html|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Guardian-Criminal-charges">{{cite web|last1=Goldenberg|first1=Suzanne|title=Los Angeles files criminal charges against SoCal Gas over massive gas leak|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/feb/02/los-angeles-gas-leak-southern-california-gas-porter-ranch|website=The Guardian|accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref> The charges include three counts of failing to immediately report the leak following its detection on October 23, 2015, and one count of "discharging air contaminants" beginning the same day.<ref name="LA-DA-Criminal charges.">{{cite web|title=District Attorney Jackie Lacey Files Criminal Charges Against SoCal Gas for Aliso Canyon Leak|url=http://da.lacounty.gov/media/news/district-attorney-jackie-lacey-files-criminal-charges-against-socal-gas-aliso-canyon-leak|website=Los Angeles County District Attorney's Office|accessdate=February 3, 2016}}</ref>
On September 13, 2016, ''The Los Angeles Times'' reported that [[SoCalGas]] reached a plea agreement with the Los Angeles County prosecutor's office. Under the agreement, [[SoCalGas]] plead no contest to one misdemeanor count of failing to immediately report the October 2015 leak and was ordered to pay a $4 million fine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-porter-ranch-settlement-20160913-snap-story.html|title=SoCal Gas to pay $4-million settlement over massive Porter Ranch gas leak|last=Times|first=Los Angeles|website=latimes.com|access-date=2016-09-13}}</ref> The resulting settlement between the local Los Angeles prosecutor's office and [[SoCalGas]] executives had ended in a mere misdemeanor charge, the lowest possible charge, which can be [[Expungement|expunged]]. In addition to the negotiated plea deal, SoCalGas had paid a penalty fine of a relatively small $4 million U.S. dollars. $4 million USD is the equivalent of the amount of revenue that [[SoCalGas]] received in profits in less than most average 12 hour time periods during the [[fiscal year]] of 2015.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WElmdWzJTzQ |title=Porter Ranch gas leak settlement angers residents |work=[[RT_America]] |accessdate=January 30, 2017 }}</ref> The Porter Ranch Gas Leak has been cited often by experts and independent tests as the largest gas leak in U.S. History.<ref>[http://www.ecowatch.com/porter-ranch-monster-gas-leak-largest-in-u-s-history-1882181666.html Article in EcoWatch.com 27 February 2016] accessed 31 January 2017</ref>
In 2018 SoCalGas agreed to payments of $119.5 million to several government entities over the incident.<ref>{{cite news |last=Domonske|first=Camila|date=8 August 2018|title=California Company Reaches $119.5 Million Settlement Over Massive Gas Leak|url=https://www.npr.org/2018/08/08/636779692/california-company-reaches-119-5-million-settlement-over-massive-gas-leak|work= |location= |access-date=17 August 2018}}</ref>

{{Infobox power station | name = Angra Nuclear Power Plant | image = Angra dos Reis - usinas nucleares.jpg | image_caption = Angra Nuclear Power Plant | location_map = Brazil | country = [[Brazil]] | coordinates = {{coord|23|00|30|S|44|27|26|W|region:BR_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | operator = [[Eletronuclear|Eletrobrás Termonuclear S.A. - Eletronuclear]] | construction_began = 1971 | commissioned = January 1, 1985 | decommissioned = | np_cooling_source = [[Atlantic Ocean|South Atlantic Ocean]] | np_cooling_towers = | ps_units_operational = 1 × {{nowrap|609 MW}}
1 × {{nowrap|1275 MW}} | ps_units_uc = 1 × {{nowrap|1245 MW}} | ps_thermal_capacity = 1 × {{nowrap|1882 MWth}}
1 × {{nowrap|3764 MWth}} | ps_electrical_capacity = 1884 | ps_electrical_cap_fac = 90.71% | ps_annual_generation = 14,971 GW·h (2016) | website = [http://www.eletronuclear.gov.br eletronuclear.gov.br] }} '''Angra Nuclear Power Plant''' is Brazil's only nuclear power plant. It is located at the '''Central Nuclear Almirante Álvaro Alberto''' ('''CNAAA''') on the Itaorna Beach in [[Angra dos Reis]], [[Rio de Janeiro (state)|Rio de Janeiro]], [[Brazil]]. It consists of two [[Pressurized water reactor]]s, '''Angra I''', with a net output of 609 [[MWe#Electrical and thermal watts|MWe]],[http://www.eletronuclear.gov.br/AEmpresa/CentralNuclear/Informa%C3%A7%C3%B5esAngra1.aspx Eletronuclear - Informações Angra 1] first connected to the power grid in 1985{{cite web|url=http://www.iaea.org/inis/collection/NCLCollectionStore/_Public/33/029/33029574.pdf|publisher=IAEA|title=Second National Report of Brazil, Nuclear Installations|accessdate=2015-04-24}} and '''Angra II''', with a net output of 1,275 MWe,[http://www.eletronuclear.gov.br/AEmpresa/CentralNuclear/Informa%C3%A7%C3%B5esAngra2.aspx Informações Angra 2] connected in 2000. Work on a third reactor, '''Angra III''', with a projected output of 1,245 MWe,[http://www.eletronuclear.gov.br/AEmpresa/CentralNuclear/Angra3.aspx Eletronuclear - Angra 3] began in 1984 but was halted in 1986. Work started again on 1 June 2010 for entry into service in 2015 and later delayed to 2018.[http://www.iaea.org/programmes/a2/ Power Reactor Information System] of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency|IAEA]]: [http://www.iaea.org/cgi-bin/db.page.pl/pris.powrea.htm?country=BR&sort=&sortlong=Alphabetic "Brazil, Federative Republic of : Nuclear Power Reactors"][http://www.eletronuclear.gov.br/Not%C3%ADcias/NoticiaDetalhes.aspx?NoticiaID=1446 "Eletronuclear - Obras civis de Angra 3 voltarão ao ritmo normal"] ==Existing complex== The '''Central Nuclear Almirante Álvaro Alberto''' complex is administrated by [[Eletronuclear]], a state company with the [[monopoly]] in nuclear power generation in Brazil. The complex employs some 3,000 people and generates another 10,000 indirect jobs in [[Rio de Janeiro (state)|Rio de Janeiro state]]. Angra I was purchased from [[Westinghouse Electric Corporation (1886)|Westinghouse]] of the [[United States|USA]] (its sister power plant is [[Krško Nuclear Power Plant]] in Sloveniahttp://entrac.iaea.org/I-and-C/TM_PRAGUE_2007_05/CD/Papers/Furieri_paper.pdf). The [[balance of plant]] design was subcontracted to Gibbs and Hill (USA) in association with PROMON Engenharia S.A. and construction to Brasileira de Engenharia S.A. The purchase did not include the transfer of sensitive reactor technology. As a result, Angra II was built with German technology, as part of a comprehensive nuclear agreement between Brazil and [[West Germany]] signed by President [[Ernesto Geisel]] in 1975. The complex was designed to have three [[Pressurized water reactor|PWR]] units with a total output of around 3,000 MWe and was to be the first of 4 nuclear plants that would be built up to 1990. ==Reactors== The plant has two [[pressurized water reactor]]s, with a total net capacity of {{nowrap|1,884 MWe}}. Its units are rated as follows: * Angra 1: 640 MWe * Angra 2: 1275 MWe ==Future developments== [[File:Construction site Angra III.JPG|thumb|260px|Construction site Angra III in May 2015]] The development of Angra III began in 1984 as a Siemens/KWU [[pressurized water reactor]] but was halted in 1986. About 70% of the plant's equipment was purchased in 1985 but has been in storage ever since. In June 2007, restarting of work on was approved by the [[National Council for Energy Policy]]. President [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva]] greenlit the project in July 2007. On December 2008, Eletronuclear signed an industrial cooperation agreement with [[Areva]]. On 31 May 2010, the [[National Nuclear Energy Commission]] granted a licence for construction of the third reactor. Construction of the reactor, which has a capacity of 1,350 MWe, begun on 1 June 2010 and was predicted to be operational by 2018. {{cite news | url= http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/NN_Construction_of_Angra_3_0206109.html | title= Angra 3 construction | date= 2010-06-02 | work= World Nuclear News | accessdate= 2010-06-18}} After stopping construction in 2014, the Brazilian government have decided to auction off the incomplete power station to private investors in 2018. Based on that timetable and the volume of construction works to complete, the Energy deputy minister expects completion to be achieved by 2023. {{cite news | url= https://www.reuters.com/article/brazil-auction-angra-iii-idUSL2N1GY0V1 | title= Brazil's Angra III nuclear project to be auctioned by 2018 -deputy minister | date= 2017-03-22 | work= Reuters | accessdate= 2017-07-21}} ==See also== {{stack|{{Portal|Brazil|Energy|Nuclear technology}}}} *[[List of power stations in Brazil]] *[[List of nuclear power stations]] {{Commons category|Angra Nuclear Power Plant}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.eletronuclear.gov.br Eletronuclear Official Website] * [http://spectrum.ieee.org/mar06/3070 How Brazil Spun the Atom] * [http://www.power-technology.com/projects/angranuclear/ Angra-3 PWR Nuclear], Brazil [[Category:Buildings and structures in Rio de Janeiro (state)]] [[Category:Nuclear power stations in Brazil]] [[Category:Nuclear power stations using pressurized water reactors]] [[Category:Nuclear power stations with reactors under construction]] [[Category:1985 establishments in Brazil]]

[[File:Sunburst edited.jpg|thumbnail|Azura prototype testing]] {{Location map |Hawaii |lat = 21.46488 |long = -157.751524 |position = none |float = right |width = 150 |AlternativeMap = |caption=Location of Azura }} '''Azura''' is a [[wave power]] device currently being tested in [[Hawaii]].<ref name="energy.gov">{{cite web|url=https://www.energy.gov/eere/articles/innovative-wave-power-device-starts-producing-clean-power-hawaii|title=Innovative Wave Power Device Starts Producing Clean Power in Hawaii|work=Energy.gov}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://subseaworldnews.com/2015/06/12/nwei-deploys-azura-wave-energy-device-in-hawaii/|title=NWEI Deploys Azura Wave Energy Device in Hawai’i|work=Subsea World News}}</ref> It is connected to the municipal [[power grid|grid]] providing electricity to Hawaii. According to the [[United States Department of Energy]], this is the first time that a wave power generator has been officially verified to be supplying energy to a power grid in North America. This has been verified by the [[University of Hawaii]].<ref name="renews.biz">{{cite web|url=http://renews.biz/89902/azura-connects-in-hawaii/|title=Azura connects in Hawaii|work=reNEWS - Renewable Energy News}}</ref><ref name="stevedent">{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2015/07/07/wave-generator-hawaii-power-grid/|title=Wave generator supplies US electrical grid for the first time|author=Steve Dent|publisher=AOL|work=Engadget}}</ref> The device can generate 20 [[kilowatt]]s of power.<ref name="energy.gov"/><ref name="gizmag.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.gizmag.com/azura-wave-energy-system-hawaii/38371/|title=Azura wave energy system deployed in Hawaii|work=gizmag.com}}</ref>
The device is at the [[Marine Corps Base Hawaii]]'s Wave Energy Test Site (WETS) on the north shore of [[Kaneohe Bay]], Oahu. It is situated on the surface of a 30-meter-deep [[Berth (moorings)|berth]] where it is being monitored.<ref name="stevedent"/>
This prototype (TRL 5/6) was developed by Northwest Energy Innovations (NWEI) with the support of the [[U.S. Navy]], the United States Department of Energy, and the University of Hawaii. It will be in operation for a 1-year period of assessment.<ref name="energy.gov"/><ref name="gizmag.com"/> During that time, the University of Hawaii will be responsible for the collection and analysis of data.<ref name="gizmag.com"/>
Azura was originally named "'''WET-NZ'''" from "Wave Energy Technology-New Zealand".
==Description and operation== Azura floats on the surface of the sea and weighs 45 tons (41 tonnes). It has a unique floating mechanism that can rotate 360 degrees. This enables it to extract power from [[Degrees of freedom (mechanics)#Six degrees of freedom|horizontal (surge) as well as vertical (heave)]] wave motion.<ref name="gizmag.com"/> It has reserve buoyancy that is very low, allowing it to partially submerge beneath large waves.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.renewableenergymagazine.com/article/azura-wave-energy-device-deployed-at-us-20150618/|title=Ocean Energy - Azura wave energy device deployed at US Navy test site - Renewable Energy Magazine, at the heart of clean energy journalism|work=renewableenergymagazine.com}}</ref> [[File:Wave float with piston rod.gif|thumbnail|[[Wave power#Point absorber buoy|Point absorber]]]] Azura is a [[Wave power#Point absorber buoy|point absorber]]. This means that it uses a floating surface mechanism to absorb the energy of waves from different directions. This is the most common type of deepwater wave energy generator.<ref name="breakingenergy.com">{{cite web|url=http://breakingenergy.com/2014/11/05/wave-energy-developers-line-up-for-hawaii-test-site/|title=Wave Energy Developers Line Up for Hawaii Test Site|work=Breaking Energy}}</ref> The generator is driven with a high-pressure hydraulics system.<ref name="breakingenergy.com"/>
==Preliminary tests== The initial phase of development used a smaller prototype that was tested in a [[wave tank]].
A second prototype was then installed in 2012 for a 6-week period at the [[Northwest National Marine Renewable Energy Center]]’s test site off the coast of [[Oregon]] in an open-sea area. During that test, the device was exposed to wave heights of up to 3.75-meters in a 12 to 14-second [[sea state]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://azurawave.com/projects/oregon/|title=Oregon Pilot Project|work=azurawave.com}}</ref>
Both tests were successful.<ref name="energy.gov"/>
==Future plans== NWEI will use information gathered during the current test to further develop the project. With the Department of Energy providing an additional 5 million dollars, NWEI plans to modify Azura to increase its efficiency and improve reliability. A new design will then be tested which will be full-scale and made to generate between 500 kilowatts and one [[megawatt]] of power.<ref name="energy.gov"/>
At the end of 2017, Northwest Energy Innovations (NWEI) intends to install a full-scale model. The 500-kilowatt to 1-megawatt generator will be situated in a 60 to 80-meter-deep (100–150 feet) berth. One megawatt is sufficient to provide electricity to several hundred homes.<ref name="renews.biz"/><ref name="stevedent"/>
